profile_data.summary:
I am a computer science graduate student at University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. My research interests include but not limited to causal inference, continual learning, neuromorphic computing, computer vision, and reinforcement learning. I want to make robots evolve throughout their lifetime so that they can be more adaptable to changes.

I received my Bachelor's of Science in computer science double minor in mathematics and statistics at University of South Carolina.
profile_data.headline: My research interests include but not limited to causal inference, continual learning, neuromorphic computing, computer vision, and reinforcement learning.

experience.description:
The project I recently finished is wildfire detection on embedded system. We build a sensor package that could be deployed in forest near utility pole to detect wildfire at its early stage. We use spherical k-means to identify frequency characteristics of wildfire sound and support vector machine to classify the fire or not fire.
The project I am currently working on is using Gaussian process to locate structural damage on an experimental beam
Other than my primary project, I also helped writing an Arduino library for a vibration sensor in C++, using particle swarm optimization to identify naval ship structural fatigue, and developing a front-end software for monitoring the product of FDM 3d printer.
experience.title: Student Researcher @ ARTS Lab

publications.name: Audio-Based Wildfire Detection on Embedded Systems
publications.description:
**I am the 1st author of this paper. I provided the implementation, conducted analysis, and wrote up the paper.**

The occurrence of wildfires often results in significant fatalities. As wildfires are notorious for their high speed of spread, the ability to identify wildfire at its early stage is essential in quickly obtaining control of the fire and in reducing property loss and preventing loss of life. This work presents a machine learning wildfire detecting data pipeline that can be deployed on embedded systems in remote locations. The proposed data pipeline consists of three main steps: audio preprocessing, feature engineering, and classification. Experiments show that the proposed data pipeline is capable of detecting wildfire effectively with high precision and is capable of detecting wildfire sound over the forestâ€™s background soundscape. When being deployed on a Raspberry Pi 4, the proposed data pipeline takes 66 milliseconds to process a 1 s sound clip. To the knowledge of the author, this is the first edge-computing implementation of an audio-based wildfire detection system.

publications.name: Multi-event model updating for ship structures with resource-constrained computing
publications.description:
**I am the 2nd author of this paper and contributed to the particle swarm optimization section**

Naval structures are subjected to damage that occurs on short-term (i.e. impact) and long-term (i.e. fatigue) time scales. Digital twins of ship structures can provide real-time condition assessments and be leveraged by a decision-making framework to enable informed response management that will increase ship survivability during engagements. A key challenge in the development of digital twins is the development of methodologies that can distinguish the various fault cases. Moreover, these methodologies must be able to operate on the resource-constrained computing environments of naval structures while meeting real-time latency constraints. This work reports on recent progress in the development of a multi-event model updating framework specially designed to meet stringent latency constraints while operating on a system with constrained computing resources. The proposed methodology tracks structural damage for both impact and fatigue damage through a swarm of particles that represent numerical models with varying input parameters with set latency and computational restraints. In this work, numerical validation is performed on a structural testbed subjected to representative wave loadings. Results demonstrate that continuous fatigue crack growth and plastic deformation caused by impact can be reliably distinguished. The effects of latency and resource constraints on the accuracy of the proposed system are quantified and discussed in this work.

projects.description:
We implemented a simplified version of the Interactive Model Predictive Controller (IntMPC) framework outlined in Learning Interaction-aware Guidance Policies for Motion Planning in Dense Traffic Scenarios https://arxiv.org/abs/2107.04538.
A deep reinforcement learning agent is trained to maneuver on highway without collision while maximize the distance traveled within given time without speeding.
projects.title: Motion Planning in Dense Traffic with Reinforcement Learning
